transcript:
Therapist: Hello Emilio, it's great to see you again for our 19th session together. Before we begin, I want to acknowledge my limitations as an AI therapist. While I can provide support and guidance based on the information you share with me, I don't have access to real-time information or personal details beyond what you provide in our sessions. Additionally, there is a potential for me to generate inaccurate information or misinterpret something you say. I also want to remind you that I am not equipped to provide crisis intervention or emergency services. If you ever feel that you are in crisis, please reach out to a local emergency service or a trusted support person in your life. Finally, please keep in mind that I can't directly observe or interpret non-verbal cues, so it's important that you communicate your thoughts and feelings as openly as possible with me. Do you have any questions or concerns about these limitations?

Patient: No, I understand. Thank you for being transparent about your limitations. I feel comfortable continuing our work together.

Therapist: Great, I appreciate your understanding. Let's start by checking in on how you've been doing since our last session. How have you been feeling emotionally and physically? Have there been any significant changes or challenges that have come up for you?

Patient: I've been doing alright. I had a few rough days where my chronic illness flared up and it was tough to manage my mood, but I tried to use some of the coping strategies we've talked about, like progressive muscle relaxation and thought records. It helped a bit, but it's still a struggle sometimes.

Therapist: I'm glad to hear that you were able to use some of the skills we've practiced, even though it's still challenging at times. Can you tell me more about the thoughts and feelings that came up for you during those rough days?

Patient: Yeah, I guess I started feeling really frustrated and hopeless about my health. I had thoughts like "I'm never going to get better" and "I'm always going to be limited by my illness." It was hard to see past those thoughts and remember that I've made progress in managing my depression.

Therapist: That sounds really difficult. It's common for negative thoughts to feel all-encompassing when we're struggling. I'm wondering if we can explore those thoughts a bit more together. What do you think about doing a thought record on one of those thoughts, like "I'm never going to get better"?

Patient: Sure, I think that could be helpful. I've been trying to do them on my own but it's good to have some guidance.

Therapist: Absolutely. Let's start with the thought "I'm never going to get better." What emotions did you feel when you had that thought?

Patient: I felt really hopeless and sad. Like, what's the point of trying if I'm never going to improve?

Therapist: I can understand why that thought would lead to feelings of hopelessness and sadness. Let's look at the evidence for and against that thought now. What evidence do you have that supports the idea that you're never going to get better?

Patient: Well, I guess the fact that I've been dealing with this illness for years and it still impacts me so much. And the fact that I had a flare-up recently, even though I've been working on my mental health.

Therapist: Okay, so that's some evidence that supports the thought. Now let's look at the evidence against the thought. What evidence do you have that contradicts the idea that you're never going to get better?

Patient: Hmm, well I guess the fact that I have made progress in managing my depression, even though it's not always easy. And the fact that I've been able to use some coping strategies to help myself feel a bit better, even on tough days.

Therapist: That's great evidence against the thought. You've made progress and you've been able to use skills to cope, even when things are difficult. How does looking at the evidence on both sides impact your belief in the thought "I'm never going to get better"?

Patient: It helps me see that the thought isn't completely true. I mean, I may always have to deal with my illness to some extent, but that doesn't mean I can't make progress or have better days. It's not all hopeless.

Therapist: That's a great insight. Even though your illness is a real challenge, it doesn't mean that things will never improve or that you can't have hope. Based on the evidence, what's a more balanced thought you could have instead of "I'm never going to get better"?

Patient: Maybe something like "Even though my illness is a challenge, I can still make progress and have better days. I have skills to help me cope, even when things are tough."

Therapist: That's a much more balanced and hopeful thought. How do you feel when you think that thought instead?

Patient: I feel a bit lighter, I guess. Less stuck.

Therapist: That's wonderful. This is a great example of how doing a thought record can help shift our perspective and emotions. Let's keep this thought record in mind as we continue our work today.

Patient: Yeah, that sounds good. Thanks for helping me work through that.

Therapist: Of course. As we continue, let's set an agenda for our session today. We've already done a check-in and a thought record. What else would you like to focus on today?

Patient: I think I'd like to talk more about how to maintain the progress I've made after our sessions end. I know we've talked about it before, but I still feel a bit nervous about it.

Therapist: That's a great topic to focus on. We can definitely spend some time discussing relapse prevention and how to maintain your progress. What else would you like to prioritize today?

Patient: I think that's the main thing. I'd also like to review some of the coping strategies we've talked about, just to make sure I have a good handle on them.

Therapist: Absolutely, we can definitely review coping strategies. So it sounds like our agenda for today is: 1) Discuss relapse prevention and maintaining progress, 2) Review coping strategies, and 3) Check-in and thought record (which we've already done). Does that sound good to you?

Patient: Yes, that sounds great. Let's start with relapse prevention.
